parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Shelf-stable, dry feline nutriments ("dry cat food" or "crunchies") must be available at all times in an accessible location, with only such wrapping or packaging to make it entertaining to extract (using only teeth and claws), or preferably, open in a bowl. Flavors based on chicken or fish are preferred.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Delicious tasty morsels of canned cat food should be provided at regular intervals in sufficient quantities for all cats to be satisfied.

parts.name: guidance
parts.prose:
Wet cat food may be referred to as "cat fud" on shopping lists. When not otherwise qualified, "cat fud" should be taken to refer to wet (i.e., canned) cat food, not dry.

Table scraps are not acceptable as wet cat food (or acceptable in general). Prey animals also do not count, although they may also be enjoyed.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Kitchen drawers and cabinets should be kept closed to prevent feline incursion.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cardboard or other disposable delivery boxes may be left in the living room as temporary cat fortresses.

guidelines.prose: A natural language description of how many treats are permitted within a given period, to be determine by the cat's "owner" given appropriate veterinary advice.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Treats may be given freely by a feline's caretaker or companion on demand, up to a maximum of {{ insert: param, p1 }}.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Any small objects or objects of any size with holes, passages, hatches or flaps may be considered cat toys, defined as objects designated for feline play. Store-bought cat toys are acceptable but a cat may select its own toys such as string, rubber bands or jewelry.
